entry.title: Custom Situation Handling in Quality Management: Get Notified when an Inspection Lot is Created
entry.content:
Use Case: ‚ÄúCreate Custom Situation Type for notifying users when an inspection lot is created‚Äù.

Even though standards apps are available which can be used to check the inspections lots created for the day. However, due to nature of the business role/responsibilities and frequency of inspection process, some users(customers) want the system to notify them via situation handling.

This blog is a detailed guide for configuring a custom situation type in SAP S/4HANA Cloud to notify users when an inspection lot is created. Here's a structured summary of the key concepts and steps:

Objective

Enable notifications (SAP Fiori home screen + email) when an inspection lot is created using Situation Handling ‚Äì Extended Framework.

Solution Overview

  • Customizable for specific business scenarios.
  • Notifications triggered by events (e.g., inspection lot creation).
  • Delivered via SAP Fiori and email.

After setting up the custom situation type, users will be able to receive notifications on their SAP home screen and via email.

 

 

Prerequisites

Apps Required:

  • Manage Situation Objects
  • Manage Teams and Responsibilities
  • Manage Responsibility Contexts
  • Manage Situation Scenarios
  • Manage Situation Types ‚Äì Extended

Roles Required:

  • BR_BUSINESS_PROCESS_SPEC
  • BR_EXTENSIBILITY_SPEC
  • BR_ADMINISTRATOR
  • BR_BPC_EXPERT
  • BR_EMPLOYEE
  • BR_EMPLOYEE_MAINTENANC

These are default SAP roles. Custom roles depend on the authorization concept can be set-up in the specific system.

Step-by-Step Setup

Key Concept: Basic steps for creating a custom situation type in S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition are outlined in the pictures below. Users can create their own situation use cases with the extended framework for Situation Handling.  The extended framework offers three new configuration apps: Mange Situation Objects, Manage Situation Scenarios, and Manage Situation Types ‚Äì Extended.

The following image illustrates the activities associated with the respective applications.

 

Step 1: Create Situation Objects

With this app, users can model business objects that facilitate Situation Handling. A situation object connects existing application artifacts, such as CDS views, events, and actions, which serve as the foundation for establishing situation use cases.

Use ‚ÄúManage Situation Objects‚Äù app.

  • Create object ID (Picture 1)
  • Use CDS view I_INSPECTIONLOT.
  • Define Structures: (Picture 2)
    • Set semantic keys and personal data fields. (Picture 2)
  • Define Events, anchor and trigger objects (Picture 3). In general anchor and trigger object are established on the situation scenario level. e.g. Inspection lot creation
    • In this situation, the anchor and trigger are the same, i.e. the inspection lot
  • Define navigation & actions (Picture 4 &5). The event corresponds to the modeled object created earlier and can be used as triggers.

(Picture 1)

(Picture 2)

(Picture 3)

(Picture 4)

While generic IDs like NAV01 are possible, the recommended naming would reflect the object and navigation target, e.g. YY1_NAV_MANAGE_INS_LOT.

(Picture 5)

While generic IDs like ACT1 are possible, the recommended naming would reflect the object and Action, e.g. YY1_ACT_MANAGE_INS_LOT.

For further information refer to : https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/a630d57fc5004c6383e7a81efee7a8bb/d973eb6d464d4dce84f354b9668ef43c.html

 

Step 2: Create Responsibility Context

Manage Responsibility Contexts in SAP lets you view, use, and extend standard or custom contexts that define who is responsible for business tasks across workflows and situation handling. A responsibility context links specific business processes or objects (like inspection lot) with rules or teams to determine the responsible agents. You can extend standard contexts or create custom ones with tailored agent rules, enabling precise assignment of responsibilities to individuals or teams for better workflow and process management.

A team is defined in the app ‚ÄòManage Teams and Responsibilities‚Äô whereas Team category is assigned in the app ‚ÄôManage Responsibility Context‚Äô. Using configuration ‚ÄòDefine Team Types‚Äô the mapping of team type and team category is done.

  • Create team in ‚ÄúManage Teams and Responsibilities‚Äù.
  • Define context in ‚ÄúManage Responsibility Contexts‚Äù.(Picture 7 &'8)
    • Add team category. (Picture 6 &'8)

(Picture 6 ‚Äì Concept)

(Picture 7)

(Picture '8)

For further information refer to the blog: https://community.sap.com/t5/enterprise-resource-planning-blog-posts-by-sap/responsibility-management-what-is-it-and-why-do-you-need-it-1-5/ba-p/13713337

 

Step 3: Create Situation Scenario

This app helps to create your own scenarios for extended object-based situations. These are situations that occur for a specific business object, like an inspection lot. A situation scenario is a technical description of a business scenario and serves as the foundation for defining multiple use cases in the form of situation templates. 

A situation scenario consists of one anchor object and one/more trigger objects. An anchor object is the object that is affected by a situation, such as an inspection lot. A trigger object creates an impact that results in situation instances for the anchor object, such as creation of an inspection lot.

Use ‚ÄúManage Situation Scenarios‚Äù.

  • Define scenario ID, type (Object-based), and structure (CDS). (Picture 9)
  • Select the anchor object and anchor object structure (Picture 9)
  • Add the instance key, i.e. the anchor object. (Picture 10)
  • Define List page layout (Picture 10).
  • Define general and specific actions. (Picture 11)
  • Define parameters for situation triggers (Picture 12 & 13) ‚Äì It can be triggered via events (e.g when inspection lot is created) or using batch jobs (e.g. running batch jobs every few hours to notify users on the created inspection lots)
  • Define Situation Page (Picture 13A) - Here user can select the field which should be populated in the notification details.

(Picture 9)

(Picture 10)

(Picture 11)

(Picture 12)

(Picture 13)

(Picture 13A)

For further information refer to: https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/a630d57fc5004c6383e7a81efee7a8bb/dfac958be2af4ce79589e8a3eaff88d6.html

 

Step 4: Create Team

This app allows users to manage teams, define responsibilities, and assign functions to team members in the Responsibility Management section. By using responsibility definitions and member functions, you can identify the members (recipients) who are responsible for workflows, business scenarios, and handling situations.

Use ‚ÄúManage Teams and Responsibility‚Äù.

  • Assign team type. The category will be automatically filled. (Picture 14)
  • Responsibility parameters will be populated automatically based on the configuration ‚ÄòAssign Custom Responsibility Definition‚Äô SSCUI- 102159 (e.g., plant)
  • Assign member functions for notification routing. The members are also not only for receiving notifications, but also for those who gets to see situations/situation instances in the app ‚ÄòMy Situations ‚Äì Extended‚Äô

(Picture 14)

For further information refer to: https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/a630d57fc5004c6383e7a81efee7a8bb/73c04858392e9244e10000000a4450e5.html

 

Step 5: Create Situation Template

Situation templates are used to define and standardize the monitoring of specific business exceptions or critical situations. These templates act as blueprints for different situation types.

Use ‚ÄúManage Situation Types ‚Äì Extended‚Äù.

  • Define template ID, scenario, and triggers. (Picture 15)
  • Choose if user needs the instances to be kept (Picture 16)
  • Set General Actions (Picture 17)
  • Define situation Triggers (Picture 18)
    • Set conditions and filters. (Picture 19, 20) e.g. Inspection type
    • Configure display and notification texts. (Picture 21)
    • Optional: define navigation actions. (Picture 22)

(Picture 15)

(Picture ‚Äì 16)

(Picture ‚Äì 17)

(Picture ‚Äì 18)

(Picture ‚Äì 19)

(Picture ‚Äì 20)

(Picture 21)

(Picture ‚Äì 22)

For further information refer to:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/a630d57fc5004c6383e7a81efee7a8bb/45d60edcf02d409c87076f9270372eb8.html

 

Step 6: Create Situation Type

Situation types describe a business situation that defines how a situation instance is triggered and who is informed about it. In the extended framework for Situation Handling, the configuration of a situation type also includes the definition of actions for solving a situation. These situations are automatically detected and addressed by identifying and handling critical events or exceptions within business processes. Situation types are derived from templates and offer customization options for conditions, notifications, responsible users, and informative texts for users. Upon activation, they generate situation instances that promptly notify the designated users, thereby enhancing process efficiency and decision-making.

Use ‚ÄúManage Situation Types ‚Äì Extended‚Äù.

  • Create situation type by copying the template created in the previous step.
  • Enable status. (Picture 23)
  • Triggers, actions, and recipients (processors) are copied from the template. For batch trigger a recurrence must be defined here. (Picture 24)
  • Use Teams or rules for processor assignment.

(Picture 23)

(Picture ‚Äì 24)

Here is an overview of the modelled custom situation template & type for this use case

(Picture ‚Äì 25)

Our recommendation is to not create IDs with spaces, so the ID would better be YY1_INSPECTION_LOT_CREATED

For further information refer to:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/a630d57fc5004c6383e7a81efee7a8bb/45d60edcf02d409c87076f9270372eb8.html

 

Step 7: Test

  • Create inspection lot manually or via goods receipt.
  • Check notifications
    • in home screen (Picture 26, 28)
    • bell icon (Picture 27, 28)
    • Email (if Email notification is enabled in the user settings) (Picture 29)
    • ‚ÄúMy Situations ‚Äì Extended‚Äù app (Picture 30)

(Picture 26)

 

(Picture 27)

 If users navigate from the notification

 

(Picture 28)

  • Description (comes from situation type)
  • Usage decision information (comes from situation scenario > situation page layout)
  • Related apps (button comes from defined actions from situation objects, detailed in situation scenario, situation template and type) 

(Picture 29)

 

(Picture 30)

 In each step only necessary information has been provided without over describing it. But to further help the readers we have provided all the necessary SAP Help links to set up their own situation handling scenario easily. 

Hope you will be able to set up your own custom situation. 

 

üîóHelpful SAP Links

  • Custom Situation Cases: Configure Your Own Use Cases
  • SAP Help | Situation Handling - Extended Framework
  • ‚ÄúAnchor-Trigger Object Mapping‚Äù: https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/a630d57fc5004c6383e7a81efee7a8bb/8955a136509345bfa3a3bc097555fcf0.html
  • For settings in section "Instances" a detailed explanation is available here: SAP Help | Situation Instances.
  • In section "Instances" the default settings are okay in most cases. For details:
    • "Monitor Instances": see SAP Help | Monitor Instances
    • "Collect data context...": see SAP Help | Collect Data Context for Instances
  • SAP Help | Situation Display.
  • SAP Help | Notifications/Life Cycle.

Latest Blog on Quality Management: https://community.sap.com/t5/enterprise-resource-planning-blog-posts-by-sap/quality-management-in-sap-s-4hana-cloud-public-edition-2508/ba-p/14167949

 

üîéFind All of Our Assets

SAP S/4HANA Cloud is the foundation of the intelligent, sustainable enterprise and is an innovative, robust, and scalable ERP. We at Cloud ERP Product Success and Cloud Co-Innovation offer a service as versatile as our product itself. Check out the numerous offerings our team has created for you below:

entry.title: Re: HXEDownloadManager can't run on windows 10
entry.content:
On my company laptop both: java -jar HXEDownloadManager.jar -h and HXEDownloadManager_win.exe (downloaded today) fail. The Java version running in Cmd.exe fails with the message:
Cannot open log file C:\Users\ROMANS~1\AppData\Local\Temp\\hxedm251126.log.

Both programs work on my private minicomputer, the difference seems to be that on the minicomputer my username (per Whoami) is just "nuc\roman" and not "azuread\romanstangl". The log file mentions hints to me that this is a filename mangling problem where NTFS directory names are converted to FAT 8.3 compatibility (the ~ was typical for that 20+ years ago, no idea why that hack is still surfacing ;-)).

The fix is to change the TMP environment variable from TMP=C:\Users\ROMANS~1\AppData\Local\Temp to e.g. TMP=D:\Temp (or even TMP=C:\Users\RomanStangl\AppData\Local\Temp).
Looks like that even Windows 11 still applies that filename mangling to the paths set in the TEMP and TMP environment variables, really astonishing.

entry.title: Innovation Day powered by SAP Women in Tech
entry.content:
November 2025 ‚Äì imagine yourself at a big tech conference.

You sit in the audience, the lights go down, and the first speakers take the stage to present the latest innovations.

After the first three talks, something stands out:
Almost everyone on stage is a woman.
A dream?

No ‚Äì reality at the Innovation Day powered by SAP Women in Tech.

19 speakers shared their business expertise and showed us what great presenters they are ‚Äì confident, passionate, and inspiring.

From AI to Sustainability, from Cybersecurity to Digital Transformation, the diversity of topics was truly impressive.

Our external speakers brought unique perspectives:
Liliana Parra Rapado (BASF) spoke about >>Customers and Society for a Sustainable Future of Agriculture<<, and Alisa Jahnke (PURELEI) shared how to build a personal brand that connects authenticity with impact.

We learned from Johannes B√ºchs how storytelling can elevate public speaking, and from Klaus Grafe how to overcome inner limiting beliefs.

entry.title: Re: Safety Stock Behavior in V2 Reorder Point Planning ‚Äì...
entry.content:
You have the below options

Keep safety stock active in MRP type ‚Üí ATP will always reduce available stock.

Remove safety stock indicator in MRP type ‚Üí Safety stock is calculated but not stored in material master, so ATP ignores it.

Alternative approach: Use Safety Time instead of Safety Stock if your goal is to buffer supply without blocking ATP. Safety Time shifts procurement dates but does not reduce available quantity.

entry.title: YTD Calculation in Restricted/Calculated Measure with 200 Dimensions in SAP DataSphere
entry.content:
Context and Goal

We are building an Analytic Model in SAP Datasphere, based on a view with approximately 200 columns/dimensions. Our goal is to calculate the Year-to-Date (YTD) value for the measure "SalesAmount". The YTD calculation must be dynamic, allowing the end-user to analyze the result by Year, Month, and any of the ~198 remaining dimensions in the model (example: Customer, Product, Region, etc.).

Attempted Solutions and Specific Issue
 We have tried to implement the YTD calculation directly within the Analytic Model, following SAP documentation:

1. Restricted Measure Attempt: 

     Expression: We defined a restricted measure for "SalesAmount" with the following filter condition on the date dimension ("SalesDate"):  SalesDate IN (YTD(SalesDate))

     Result: The model fails to activate. Upon deployment, Datasphere throws the following syntax error:

           Reason: Invalid syntax or usage of unsupported function. unexpected character: ->Y<- at offset: 0, skipped 3 characters.

Observation: The YTD() function does not seem to be recognized or supported in this context/syntax, despite being suggested by the expression editor.

2. Calculated Measure Attempt:

  • Expression: We also tried creating a calculated measure using the YTD() function:  YTD(SalesAmount, SalesDate)

  • Result: The outcome is the same; the model fails to activate and shows the identical syntax error related to the 'Y' character.

3. SQL View Implementation (Window Function):

  • Approach: We tried calculating the running total using the OVER (PARTITION BY Year ORDER BY Month) window function within the source view (View Builder).

  • Limitation: This approach is unworkable because it limits the drill-down capability. The calculation is performed only at the Year/Month level, and since it is a calculated column in the view, we cannot dynamically disaggregate the YTD by the other ~198 dimensions in the model (e.g., if we filter by a specific "Customer", the calculated YTD would still be the total across all customers up to that "Month").

4. SAC (SAP Analytics Cloud) - Import Model Test:

  • Approach: We created an Import Model in SAC, and there, the YTD() function (implemented as a calculated account) works perfectly and allows for dynamic drill-down across all dimensions.

  • Limitation: This forces us to lose the Real-Time capability of SAP Datasphere and the Live Connection, which is an unacceptable trade-off for our use case.

Question to the Community

Is there an alternative, supported syntax or method in SAP Datasphere, within the Analytic Consumption Model (or a dynamically aggregate-aware View Builder approach) to calculate YTD while respecting all dimensions in the model?

Any workaround or confirmation on whether the YTD() function in Restricted or Calculated Measures is actually supported in the current version of Datasphere would be highly appreciated.

Thank you in advance for your assistance!

entry.title: Re: Material Management - Release Strategy
entry.content:
Hi @Eddie88 ,
Correct, you should review and adjust the ‚ÄúChgable‚Äù (changeable) settings in your release strategy configuration. The ‚ÄúDelivery Complete‚Äù (ELIKZ) flag is technically treated as a change to the PO item, and if your release strategy is configured to re-trigger on any change, it will cause a new release cycle. Best practice is to mark statistical or non-commercial fields (like ELIKZ) as non-change relevant so they don‚Äôt reset the release strategy

I would like to recommend you these adjustments.
1. Check release strategy configuration (SPRO path)
Materials Management ‚Üí Purchasing ‚Üí Purchase Order ‚Üí Release Procedure. Review the Changeability Indicator for your release strategy.

2. Set ‚ÄúChgable‚Äù appropriately
Use option 2 (Changeable, new release in case of changes) only for commercial/critical fields (price, quantity, vendor). For statistical fields like ELIKZ, set 4 (Changeable, no new release in case of changes) so updates don‚Äôt trigger a new release.

3. Test in QA first
Perform a mass update of ELIKZ in your test system. Confirm that the release strategy remains stable and does not reset.

4. Alternative approach:
If business policy requires strict control, you can exclude ELIKZ from mass updates and instead automate its setting via GR/IR processes (SAP Note 1093582 explains how ELIKZ can be auto-set during goods receipt or invoice posting)

The Best Practice is as mentioned below.
Differentiate between commercial vs. statistical changes: Only commercial changes should re-trigger release. Automate ELIKZ where possible, Configure tolerance ranges so the system sets ‚ÄúDelivery Complete‚Äù automatically after final GR. Communicate with stakeholders and Ensure procurement and finance teams agree on which fields should be release-relevant.

Hope my suggestion is fine with you.

entry.title: Re: SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud: Disassembly Production Order
entry.content:
Hello @AngelT

Answer to question 1: Yes, it is because C007 orders have no header material, therefore there is nothing to deliver. Delivery logic only exists for production orders you create with a material. In your case the open quantity will remain 1 PC and will not affect your costing, stock or accounting.

Answer to point 2: See answer 1.

Answer to question 3: Yes, it is. All GR postings are automatically non-valuated, only the component consumptions posts to FI. That is the expected journal entry for disassembly. In your case nothing has been consumed and hence why no change in quantity.

Answer to question 4: The delivery completed status on C007 orders is a formal administrative flag. It does not trigger goods receipts or effects stock and does not change the behaviour of open quantity. If you mark it as completed it will not change logistics or accounting details.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Subscription Management for Software (5SW)
entry.content:
In today‚Äôs software-driven business environment, subscription-based models are increasingly the norm. Managing subscriptions, entitlements, usage, billing  and revenue recognition can become complex without a robust system in place. SAP addresses this challenge with an integrated end-to-end process across SAP Cloud ERP, SAP Subscription Billing, and SAP Entitlement Management. This solution simplifies subscription management while enabling automation and comprehensive insights into software usage and revenue.

With 2508 release SAP has provided an end-2-end Best Practice content for Software and SaaS use cases. The goal of this Best Practice is to significantly reduce time-to-value by providing clear setup instructions for common processes along the end-2-end value chain. The Best Practice content is provided via the new scope item 5SW (link to scope item in the Process Navigator).

 

What does Scope Item 5SW cover?

This scope item enables a seamless process for the full lifecycle of software subscriptions. From subscription modeling and pricing to fulfillment, billing, and revenue recognition, the integration ensures all steps are connected:

  • Subscription Modeling & Pricing: Define software subscription products, base and add-on licenses, and pricing models.
  • Sales & Fulfillment: Sell subscriptions through solution orders in SAP Cloud ERP and manage provisioning in SAP Entitlement Management.
  • License & Usage Management: Track entitlements, license consumption, and software usage to ensure compliance and optimize revenue.
  • Billing & Revenue Recognition: Automate billing for recurring, one-time, and usage-based charges, and ensure accurate revenue recognition.
  • End-of-Life Processes: Decommission licenses and tenants at the end of subscription contracts efficiently.

This scope item consolidates several existing capabilities, including Subscription Management with Sales Billing, corresponding capabilities of Solution Order Management, and Event-Based Revenue Recognition, Subscription Billing, extended with SAP Entitlement Management functionalities.

Key Process Flow

Process Flow

  1. Creation or Update of the Solution Order
    The Solution Order Specialist initiates the process by creating a new Solution Order or updating an existing one. This serves as the foundation for all subsequent subscription and billing activities.
  2. Automatic Subscription Creation in SAP Subscription Billing
    If the Solution Order includes a subscription item, a corresponding subscription is automatically created in SAP Subscription Billing with a pending status. This ensures that the subscription lifecycle is immediately tracked and initialized.
  3. Entitlement Assignment and Provisioning
    In SAP Entitlement Management, entitlements can be added to the subscription to define the customer‚Äôs access rights. Once entitlements are assigned, tenant and license provisioning are triggered to enable the actual usage.
  4. Subscription Finalization and Activation
    After entitlement configuration and provisioning, the subscription is finalized and activated. This marks the transition from setup to operational use.
  5. Automatic Creation of Provider Contract and Billing Plan
    With the subscription activated, SAP Cloud ERP automatically generates the Provider Contract and the associated billing plan. These define the contractual framework and scheduling for invoicing.
  6. Revenue Recognition
    Based on the activated subscription and billing data, Revenue Recognition can be monitored in the SAP Cloud ERP system.

 

  1. Detection of Billing Cycle End
    Once the end of the billing cycle is detected, the process for capturing license usage begins. In SAP Entitlement Management, both software consumption and actual license utilization are recorded.
  2. Transfer and Rating of Usage Data
    The recorded usage data is automatically sent to SAP Subscription Billing. There, it is rated according to the predefined price models and tariff rules.
  3. Automatic Billing in SAP Subscription Billing
    Based on the consumed quantity and the billing cycle, SAP Subscription Billing automatically generates bills. This eliminates manual effort and ensures consistent and rule-based billing.
  4. Creation of Billing Document Request (BDR)
    The generated bills are transferred to SAP Cloud ERP, where a Billing Document Request (BDR) is created. This serves as the foundation for further processing in the ERP system.
  5. Generation of Billing Documents
    Using the BDR, the final Billing Documents are created in SAP Cloud ERP. They contain all relevant billing information and can be used for financial posting and customer communication.
  6. Event-Based Revenue Recognition
    Finally, event-based Revenue Recognition is executed. This ensures that revenue is posted in compliance with accounting standards, enabling accurate financial reporting.

  1. Decommissioning of Tenants and Licenses
    Once the subscription contract reaches its end, the associated tenants and licenses can be properly decommissioned. This ensures that access is revoked, resources are released, and the offboarding process is completed in a controlled manner.

 

Business Benefits

Implementing this integrated scope item delivers significant advantages:

  • End-to-End Automation: Streamline modelling, selling, fulfillment, and billing of software subscriptions.
  • Flexible License Management: Use generic license templates for multiple applications, tenant types, and metrics.
  • Efficient Provisioning & Updates: Automate updates, add-ons, and decommissioning of licenses and tenants.
  • Usage Insights: Monitor adoption, detect low, and prevent revenue leakage from overuse.
  • Flexible Billing Models: Support recurring, one-time, and usage-based billing.
  • Integrated Revenue Recognition: Ensure compliance and accuracy in multi-license scenarios.

Conclusion

By combining SAP Cloud ERP, SAP Subscription Billing, and SAP Entitlement Management, businesses can achieve a fully integrated, automated subscription management process to explicitly cover common requirements of software & SaaS use cases. This approach not only reduces operational complexity but also enhances visibility into software usage, adoption, and revenue‚Äîempowering companies to maximize value from their subscription offerings.

For further information or any questions, you can reach out to me:

Faruk Gedik (Business Process Consultant), faruk.gedik@sap.com

and I will be happy to assist you.

entry.title: Re: What Tax Group should be tagged when purchasing to a...
entry.content:
Hi @Ivan123,
When purchasing from an international supplier in SAP, you typically tag the transaction with an Input Tax Group (A/P tax group) that reflects Import/Zero-rated VAT or a custom tax code configured for imports. The exact tax group depends on your country‚Äôs tax regulations (e.g., ‚ÄúImport VAT,‚Äù ‚ÄúNo Tax,‚Äù or ‚ÄúReverse Charge‚Äù) and how your SAP system is localized.

Which country are you operating in?
For example:
In Saudi Arabia, imports are subject to VAT at customs, so you‚Äôd use an ‚ÄúImport VAT‚Äù tax group.
In the EU, you‚Äôd often apply a ‚ÄúReverse Charge‚Äù tax code for intra-EU suppliers.
In the US, many companies tag international purchases as ‚ÄúNo Tax‚Äù but may apply use tax later.
Once I know your country, I can give you the exact SAP tax group setup that fits your local compliance requirements.

entry.title: Intra Company Stock transport order with Advanced shipping and receiving (ASR) in SAP S/4HANA 2025
entry.content:
Transfer of goods from one plant to another plant within the same company code as depicted in the image below is very common in supply chain.

SAP note 3289977 states ‚ÄúStock Transport Orders are not yet supported for scenarios with EWM‚Äù. It means that if the storage location in either (or both) of the supplying and receiving plant/s  is EWM (Extended warehouse management) managed, then TM (Transportation management) does not support the same.

If we go a bit deeper on SAP functionality, the freight unit created from stock transfer order (STO) and / or outbound delivery (from STO) does not get assigned the inbound delivery (which is created after post goods issue on outbound delivery) as depicted in below image for S/4HANA prior to 2023 FPS0 release.

However, that limitation has now been eliminated with S/4HANA 2025 FPS0 release for embedded ASR (Advanced shipping & receiving) as depicted in below image.

Embedded ASR (Advanced shipping & receiving) with S/4HANA 2025 FPS0 has the capability to assign the freight unit from outbound delivery at outbound shipping point to inbound delivery at inbound shipping point as depicted in below image from ‚ÄòOverview‚Äô tab of TM Freight order.

All 3 SAP documents (Stock transfer order , outbound delivery, inbound delivery) are assigned to the same freight unit (and freight order) as displayed in below image. 

Note this functionality is now possible with

  • 2 step intracompany stock transfer order (i.e the goods receipt at receiving plant is NOT posted at the same time as the goods issue is posted in the issuing plant)
  • Embedded ASR (i.e ASR is not in decentralized environments)

And not possible with 2025 FPS0 (but expected in future release)

  • Intercompany stock transfer order
  • Decentral ASR

This blog is based on my personal tests , observations , insights in S/4HANA 2025 FPS0  release. Will appreciate your feedback / comments.

PS : Refer my blog https://community.sap.com/t5/supply-chain-management-blog-posts-by-members/cross-delivery-handling-unit-in-advanced-shipping-and-receiving-asr-in-sap/ba-p/14264798 for another new feature of ASR in S/4HANA 2025 FPS0 release.

entry.title: Re: 999 ‚Äì The Number of the BSEG
entry.content:
Hello Jack,

sure, the classical GUI transactions from FI will not process the BAdi AC_DOCUMENT, just the logistical transactions and yes, the FIORI app postings, too, but what you could do is restrict your OB27 validation to just these classical FI GUI transactions (e.g. by a precondition like BKPF-AWTYP = 'BKPF'). Because for these FB01 postings, no BSEGs will ever be summarized, so no functional area will be cleared for summarization here either! And cover all the other ones with the BAdi AC_DOCUMENT. The GLT0_AFTERSPLIT_VAL is not a problem, it's also based on ACCIT records, not on - possibly summarized - BSEG records.

Kind regards, 

Stefan

entry.title: Activating Embedded WalkMe Workflows in SAP Sales Cloud V1 and SAP Sales and Service Cloud V2
entry.content:
Activating Embedded WalkMe Workflows in SAP Sales Cloud V1 and SAP Sales and Service Cloud V2

WalkMe is a powerful digital adoption tool that helps users navigate applications through interactive, on-screen guidance. WalkMe, embedded within SAP Sales Cloud V1 and SAP Sales & Service Cloud V2, provides interactive, step-by-step guidance directly inside the application‚Äîhelping users navigate processes with confidence.

In this blog, I will walk you through the steps to activate WalkMe in both V1 and V2, along with an overview of all available embedded workflows.

Activating WalkMe in SAP Sales Cloud V1

Step 1: Navigate to Settings -> Company Settings, under General tab locate ‚ÄúDisable WalkMe‚Äù. By Default, this option is enabled which means WalkMe is turned off.

Switch off the toggle to activate WalkMe.

 

 

Step 2: Click on ‚ÄúSave‚Äù. Refresh your browser and a WalkMe Icon will appear on the Shell bar.

Click the WalkMe Icon on shell bar. A list of all available embedded WalkMe workflows will appear. Select any WalkMe Walk-Thru to begin. System will guide you through the process with on-screen instructions.

Available WalkMe Workflows in SAP Sales Cloud V1

The following WalkMe Workflows are currently available in SAP Sales Cloud v1. These workflows help users smoothly navigate basic Sales Cloud processes.

  • Home Screen Tour
  • Create Lead
  • Convert Lead to Opportunity
  • Run a Pipeline Simulation

Activating WalkMe in SAP Sales & Service Cloud V2

Step 1: Navigate to Settings-> User Settings. Under System Preference click on WalkMe

 
 

 

Step 2: Switch on the toggle labelled ‚ÄúActivate WalkMe‚Äù and click Save

Step 3: Refresh your Browser. You will now see WalkMe Icon in the shell bar. Click the icon to view the list of available WalkMe Workflows. You can expand either:

  • Sales Cloud for Sales-related use-cases.
  • Service Cloud for Service-related use-cases.

Available Embedded WalkMe Workflows in V2:

A. Sales Cloud V2

  • Welcome to SAP Sales Cloud
  • Create a Lead
  • Create an Opportunity
  • Creates a Sales Quote

B. Service Cloud V2

  • Welcome to SAP Service Cloud
  • Create an Email Channel
  • Create Case types
  • Review case filters
  • Review a live case

The embedded WalkMe workflows available in SAP Sales Cloud V1 and SAP Sales & Service Cloud V2 are designed to introduce users to the fundamental capabilities of WalkMe. These basic walkthroughs provide a helpful starting point‚Äîgiving users a feel for how in-application guidance works and how it can support day-to-day processes.

entry.title: Re: Sales withholding tax differences between SD/FI document
entry.content:
Below are the root cause

  • In SD, condition type ZWC1 calculates 1.2% of net invoice value = COP 31,200.
  • In FI, however, the posting logic is not simply ‚Äútake the SD condition value.‚Äù Instead, FI applies the withholding tax type/code configuration you‚Äôve set up:
    • WH Tax Type 86 with Tax Code 01 is active in the BP.
    • FI then recalculates withholding tax based on the withholding tax procedure (net amount √ó percentage).
    • Because you have Post with tax amount ticked and Post indicator = 3, FI posts the tax amount at tax code level, not the SD condition value.
    • The discrepancy (65,000 vs 31,200) suggests FI is applying a different base amount than SD ‚Äî likely the gross invoice base or including additional conditions (e.g., freight, surcharges) that SD excluded.

Why FI shows 65,000 is because Post indicator 3 means ‚ÄúPost withholding tax amount at tax code level‚Äù. So FI ignores the SD condition value and recalculates based on the FI tax code setup. If FI interprets the base as COP 5,416,666 (instead of 2,600,000), then 1.2% = COP 65,000. That‚Äôs consistent with what you‚Äôre seeing. This happens because FI uses its own withholding tax base determination rules, not the SD condition base.

Options to align SD and FI are

If you want FI to post the SD condition value (31,200), set the Post Indicator = 1 (Manual entry/condition value) instead of 3. This way, FI takes the SD-calculated amount directly.

In SSCUI ‚ÄúAssign Condition Types to Withholding Tax Types‚Äù, ensure ZWC1 is mapped only once to the correct WH Tax Type. Right now, you have ZWC1 mapped to both 86 and 88, which can cause duplication or override.

entry.title: Re: ABAP in ADT ‚Äì Missing Variable Templates and Alternatives?
entry.content:
Okay, let me explain better with example.

I imagine the usage like this. Lets say I have following APPEND statment that I use often.

APPEND VALUE #( group       = 'C'
                number      = 500
                description = `Group C-2` ) TO initial_data.

In my current Eclipse ADT I can define template like this

APPEND VALUE #( group = '${group}' 
                number = ${number)
                description = `${desc}`) TO ${table}.
${cursor}

When template is trigered, I can jump between the ${} variables using Tab. The current template allows me to generate the base structure, but

  • I have to change ${table} variable every time.  
  • I can't list relevant options for Ctrl+Space to choose from (Assume that group field has only few options).

Assuming that I work with initial_data frequently, and have predefined options for group field, I would like to enhance my template like this

APPEND VALUE #( group = '${options:{A,B,C}}' 
                number = ${number)
                description = `${desc}`) TO ${default:initial_table}.
${cursor}

This template should allow me to

  • Jump between ${}
  • When inside ${options:{A,B,C}}, I can get suggestion from Ctrl+Space to fill listed values inside the brackets.
  • The initial_table is filled automatically, however I can override it when I want to 

 I found this usage for other programing languages (like Java), however the ADT extension does not provide such keywords for templates (Note that I dont know the exact keyword (option,  default), these serves only as a demonstration of what i want to do).

Hopefully this clarifies my intentions.

entry.title: Procurement process Brazil
entry.content:
Hello All,

We have a specific requirement where I would need inputs from bright minds out there. 

Plant 1000: Demand is created in plant from different sources.

Plant 1001: No procurement to be done from this plant. This plant will hold stock and supply to plant 1000.

Scenario:

Demand created in plant 1000, if stock is in plant 1001, then it should be supplied to plant 1000 from 1001 (Stock transfer scheduling agreement) else material should be procured from supplier into 1001 using purchase scheduling agreement.  

In purchase scheduling agreement, delivery address could be of plant 1001. When supplier ships, ASN in SAP to create inbound delivery  within plant 1000 but physically goods are going to plant 1001 directly.  Inbound delivery when goods receipted into 1000 should trigger automatic transfer of goods from 1000 to 1001 plant with exact same information ( STO scheduling agreement - > OBD -> IBD). The GR is done in 1001 plant using Inbound delivery document.

When a demand is created in plant 1000, stock from plant 1001 is transferred to 1000 else stock sits in plant 1000.

Here, we have requirement to hold stock in plant 1001 and on demand can be sent to plant 1000 but plant 1001 is not to perform any procurement.

Kindly suggest how this can be achieved in standard SAP or how it can be done with custom development.

Regards,

Arvind

entry.title: The Buyer‚Äôs Choice? It‚Äôs SAP BTP!
entry.content:
It‚Äôs been another great year for reviews of SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP) on the Trust Radius review platform. Having received the coveted Top Rated award earlier this year, we‚Äôre now preparing to step out in style next year having also recently been awarded with the Trust Radius Buyer‚Äôs Choice award for 2026.

Of course, we rely entirely on our wonderful customers to win awards like this, as they are the ones who are kind enough to share their thoughts and experiences in the reviews they write about us.  Awards are then given based on assessment of review submissions, and with qualification for the Buyer‚Äôs Choice award being made on the basis that 75% of customer reviews rate products as best in capabilities, value for price, and customer relationship, we know that we‚Äôre getting something right. And our prize for this, is a new badge to add to our growing collection.

 

A variety of experiences shared in the form of unique reviews

Customers familiar with the Trust Radius review submission form will know that this follows a set question structure, however the way in which customers respond is always different, depending upon their own system landscape and unique business needs. The result is an extensive list of reviews which describe how customers use SAP BTP in a variety of ways, from integration to user experience, to clean core among others.

Here are some examples of the most recent use cases:

  • Extensibility using SAP BTP to build a SoD software for SAP ERP (15 Nov ‚Äò25)
  • Clean core extensions using modern low code tools on SAP Build (15 Nov ‚Äò25)
  • App development used to build an AI-enabled Promotion Management App (14 Nov ‚Äò25)
  • Integrate & extend to create user interfaces and extensions for SAP SuccessFactors across onboarding and recruitment modules (14 Nov ‚Äò25)
  • Integration with SAP and non-SAP systems (7 Nov ‚Äô25)
  • Integrate & automate to help streamline operations and automate repetitive tasks (7 Nov ‚Äô25)

And this is just a small sample of the 71 reviews that customers have left in the last month alone, but which serve to show how SAP BTP is used to meet the different needs of customers across lines of business and industries, whether in SAP- or hybrid-solution landscapes.

If you‚Äôre interested to read more, then I‚Äôd recommend that you take a look at the SAP BTP review page on Trust Radius, where you‚Äôll find all current reviews listed ‚Äì and you can filter to view those most relevant to you. And if you use SAP BTP in your company, and you‚Äôre inclined, I‚Äôd also welcome you to leave a review whilst you‚Äôre there too, so that you can share your own experience with others.

Happy reading!

Chris Grundy, Product Marketing, SAP BTP

entry.title: Re: BW Note Validation in SAC: Instantly see whether your BW backend is up to date
entry.content:
Hi Michael, 

It will use the SAC wave version of the tenant it is run on. So it checks the difference from preview tenant to backend. 

It does not check which notes are missing in particular, it only calculates how many QRC/SP notes are missing. This is just a general hint for the story developer if the backend system is on par with the frontend. 

Best regards, 
Sajoscha

entry.title: Re: SAP MDG does not have does not have field for return supplier but the same in S4 -BP
entry.content:
Please note that this is now available with MDG on S/4 HANA 2023 version. Details here: https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_ON-PREMISE/7113856e409647838af7891e1429b807/17cf366407064fed90ace75b3d35dd9b.html

 

You can maintain the Returns Supplier indicator for a supplier. The can be set if a valid customer is assigned in the ERP Vendor: Control Data UIBB. The KZRET indicator is reflected in the BP data model in entity type BP_PORG and UIBB ERP Vendor Purchasing Data: Control Data.

Read ZKRET as KZRET in the link as original field name is KZRET.

entry.title: Re: Procurement process Brazil
entry.content:
Some standard options are

1. MRP Area / Special Procurement Key
Define a special procurement key for materials in Plant 1000:

  • First source: Stock transfer from Plant 1001.
  • Second source: External procurement (vendor).

This way, MRP in Plant 1000 will first check 1001 stock, and if insufficient, trigger external procurement. Procurement proposals (Purchase Scheduling Agreement) are created in Plant 1000, but delivery address can be set to Plant 1001. But the limitation is the inbound delivery will be created for Plant 1001 (since that‚Äôs the delivery address). You‚Äôd need custom logic if you want the inbound delivery technically in 1000 but physically received in 1001.

2. Stock Transport Orders with Scheduling Agreements
Maintain STO Scheduling Agreement between 1001 ‚Üí 1000. When demand arises in 1000, system checks 1001 stock and creates STO. If stock is not available, MRP in 1000 triggers external procurement. Supplier delivers to 1001, and then you manually or automatically trigger STO to move stock to 1000. But here, the limitation is the ‚Äúautomatic transfer‚Äù from 1000 to 1001 after GR is not standard. You‚Äôd need enhancement.

3. Vendor ‚Üí Plant 1001 Direct Delivery with Cross‚ÄëDocking
Supplier delivers directly to Plant 1001. You configure cross‚Äëdocking / direct stock transfer so that inbound delivery in 1001 automatically generates an STO to 1000. This requires custom BAdI / enhancement because standard SAP does not automatically create STO after GR
